bibl.title: Lee Fong v. John Sullivan. Answer
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: United States District Court for the District of Washington

div1.ab: IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, IN AND FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of Lee Fong for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
ANSWER.
div1.p: Comes now John Sullivan, as Chief of Police of the City of Seattle, King County, Washington, and in compliance with the order from this Honorable Court, and in answer to petition herein, says: That he is the Chief of Police of the City of Seattle, and the one to whom the order in this cause was directed, and on whom served, and the one having in charge and custody at said time the said Lee Fong, and this much of the allegations of the petition is admitted, but as to each and every other allegation contained in said petition, he has not sufficient knowledge or informtion upon which to form a belief, and therefore denies each and every other allegation contained in said petition.

John Sullivan, as Chief of Police of the City of Seattle, King County, Washington, further answering said petition, and for cause why he had said petitioner in his custody and why a writ of habeas corpus should not issue, says:

That on the 29th day of August, 1902, a complaint was filed before Hon. R. R. George, one of the Justices of the Peace and Police Judge in and for the City of Seattle, charging the defendant, Lee Fong, with the violation of Sections

6 and 7 of Ordinance No. 710 of the City of Seattle, and upon said complaint being filed, a warrant was issued from said Court directing the said Sullivan to make the arrest of said Lee Fong, and by reason of the authority of said complaint and warrant, the said Lee Fong was in the custody of said Sullivan as Chief of Police. A certified copy of said warrant and complaint, as well as a certified copy of said ordinance, are hereby attached, referred to and made a part of this answer.
div1.ab: John Sullivan
Chief of Police of the City of Seattle.
State of Washington, County of King.
ss.
div1.p: JOHN SULLIVAN, being first duly sworn, says: That he is the Chief of Police of the City of Seattle, King County, Washington, and the one upon whom was served an order from this Honorable Court to show cause why a writ of habeas corpus should not issue for Lee Fong, and the one having in charge the said Lee Fong at the time of the service of said order, and that he has read the answer herein, knows fully the contents thereof, and believes the same to be true.
div1.ab: John Sullivan
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 4th day of September, 1902.
Ellis E Butler
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
THE CITY OF SEATTLE IN THE JUSITCE COURT IN AND FOR SEATTLE PRECINCT King County, Washington.
Before R. R. George, Police Judge.
THE CITY OF SEATTLE vs. Lee Fong.
Criminal Complaint.
STATE OF WASHINGTON, County of King, The City of Seattle..
ss.
div1.p: F. E. BRYANT, being first duly sworn, says: That on the 29th day of August 1902, at the City of Seattle, in said King County, Washington, the said Lee Fong did commit a misdemeanor as follows, to-wit by carrying on a public laundry without any permit from the City Council, to-wit: Then and there being the said defendant, Lee Fong, did wilfully and unlawfully, at Number 1410 Fir Street, in said City of Seattle, establish, maintain and carry on a laundry within the corporate limits of the said City of Seattle and at said place, without first obtaining the consent of the City Council of said City, the said laundry not being located in a building constructed either of brick, stone, nor covered with a metal roof, all of which is contrary to Ordinance No. 710, Sections 6 and 7, of the City of Seattle, entitled "An Ordinance regulating the establishment and maint enance of public laundries and public wash-houses within
the limits of the City of Seattle, approved February 6, 1886, and against the public morals, peace and good order of the City of Seattle.
div1.ab: F. E. Bryant
Subscribed and sworn to before me, this 30th day of August, 1902.
R. R. George Police Judge.
WARRANT OF ARREST.
THE CITY OF SEATTLE, Plaintiff, vs. Lee Fong, Defendant.
WARRANT
State of Washington, County of King, The City of Seattle.
ss.
In Justice Court, Seattle Precinct, R.R. George, Police Judge.
div1.p: THE STATE OF WASHINGTON to the CHIEF OF POLICE OF SAID CITY, OR SHERIFF OR CONSTABLE OF SAID COUNTY, GREETING:

WHEREAS, F. E. Bryant has this day complained in writing, under oath, to the undersigned, one of the Justices of the Peace and Police Judge in and for said Seattle Precinct, King County, that on the 29th day of August, 1902, Lee Fong, in said City, County and State, did commit the offense of unlawfully establishing, maintaining and carrying on a laundry in said city without a permit from the City Council of said City.
WHEREFORE, In the name of the State of Washington, you are commanded forthwith to apprehend the said Defendant and bring him before me to be dealt with according to Law.
Given under my hand this 3rd 30th day of August, 1902.
div1.ab: R.R. GEORGE Police Judge.
STATE OF WASHINGTON, County of King, The City of Seattle.
ss.
div1.p: I Hereby Certify, That I have arrested the within named Lee Fong and have him now in court. John Sullivan Chief of Police.
div1.ab: By F. E. Bryant, Police Officer.
STATE OF WASHINGTON, County of King, City of Seattle.
ss.
div1.p:
I, R. R. George, a Justice of the Peace and Police Judge of the City of Seattle, King County, Washington, do hereby certify that the foregoing and annexed complaint and warrant is a true and correct copy of the original complaint and warrant in said cause on file in my office, the same being the case of The City of Seattle,
Plaintiff, vs. Lee Fong, Defendant,
and that the annexed and attached papers are all the process and other papers relating to the action and filed with me, and all of which is correct.
div1.ab: Dated at Seattle, Washington, -by- day of September, 1902.
R. R. George Police Judge of the City of Seattle.
ORDINANCE NO. 710.
div1.p: AN ORDINANCE regulating the establishment and maintenance of public laundries and public wash-houses within the limits of the City of Seattle.

WHEREAS, The indiscriminate establishment of public laundries and public wash-houses, where clothes and other articles are cleaned for hire, is injurious and dangerous to public health and public safety, and prejudicial to the well-being and comfort of the community and depreciates the value of the property in those neighborhoods where such public laundries and such public wash-houses are situate:
The City of Seattle does ordain as follows:

Section 1. On and after the passage of this ordinance it shall be unlawful for any person or persons to establish, maintain or carry on the business of a public laundry or a public wash-house, where clothes or other articles are cleansed for hire, wtihin the corporate limits of the City of Seattle, without having first complied with the conditions hereinafter specified.

Sec. 2. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to conduct or maintain a public laundry or wash-house within the city of Seattle without having first obtained a certificate signed by the health officer of the City of Seattle that the premises are properly and sufficiently drained and that all proper arrangements for carrying on the business without injury to the sanitary conditions of the neighborhood have been complied with, also a certificate signed by the chief of the fire department of the City of Seattle that the stoves, washing and drying apparatus and

the appliances for heating smoothing irons are in good condition, and that their use is not dangerous to the surrounding property from fire, and that all proper precautions have been taken to comply with the provisions of the ordinances of the city then in force making regulations concerning the erection and use of buildings and for the protection of property from injury or destruction by fire.

Sec. 3. It shall be the duty of the health officer, also of the chief of the fire department, respectabively, upon application from any person or persons proposing to open or conduct the business of a public laundry within the City of Seattle to inspect the premises in which it is proposed to carry on said business, or in which said business is being carried on, with a view to ascertain whether the said premises are provided with proper drainage and sanitary appliances, also whether the provisions of the ordinances of the city then in force making regulations concerning the erection and use of buildings and for the protection of property from fire or injury or destruction by fire, have been complied with, and if found in all respects satisfactory then to issue to such person or persons the certificates provided for in section 2 of this ordinance. No charge whatever shall be made or compensation or fee collected or received for the performance of any of the services required by the provisions of this ordinance in the inspection of premises or the issuance of a certificate, but all such services shall be performed free of charge.

Sec. 4. No person or persons owning or employed in the public laundries or public wash-houses provided for in section 1 of this ordinance shall wash or iron clothes between the hours of 10 o'clock p.m. and 6 a.m., nor upon
any portion of that day known as Sunday.

Sec. 5. No person or persons engaged in the laundry business within the City of Seattle shall permit any person suffering from any infectious or contagious disease to lodge, sleep or remain within or upon the premises used by him, her or them for the purpose of a public laundry.

Sec. 6. It shall be unlawful, from and after the passage of this ordinance, for any person or persons to establish, maintain or carry on a laundry within the corporate limits of the City of Seattle, without having first obtained the consent of the common council, except the same be located in a building constructed either of brick or stone and covered with a metal roof.

Sec. 7. Any person or persons establising, maintaining or carrying on the business of a public laundry or a public wash-house where clothes or other articles are cleansed for hire, within the limits or the City of Seattle, without first having complied with the provisions of section 2 of this ordinance, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars nor more than one hundred dollars, or by imprisonment for not more than thirty days, or by both such fine and imprisonment; and any person who shall violate any of the provisions of sections 4, 5 and 6 of this ordinance shall be guilty of a misdemenor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than five dollars nor more than one hundred dollars, or by imprisonment for not more than thirty days, or by both such fine and imprisonment.

Sec. 8. The certificates from the health officer and the chief of the fire department, as required by section 2 of this ordinance, shall be exhibited in some conspicuous place on the premises, and the same shall be produced on the demand of any officer of the City of Seattle.
Sec. 9. The police authorities are hereby directed to have the provisions of this ordinance strictly enforced.

Sec. 10. Ordinance No. 263, entitled "An ordinance to restrain and regulate laundries and wash-houses within the fire limits of the City of Seattle for the purpose of the prevention of fires," approved April 10, 1882, and all other ordinances and parts of ordinance are hereby repealed; provided, that this ordinance shall not in any manner affect any cause or proceeding pending or being prosecuted at the time this ordinance takes effect or that may be hereafter commenced and prosecuted for violations of said ordinance No. 263 committed prior to the time of the passage of this ordinance; but, as to all such past violations, said ordinance No. 263 shall be and remain in full force.
Sec. 11. This ordinance shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage and approval by the Mayor.
Passed the Common Council of the City of Seattle the 5th day of February, 1886, and approved by me the 6th day of February, 1886.
div1.ab: H. L. Yesler, Mayor.
div1.p: Filed February 6th, 1886.
div1.ab: W. R. Forrest, Clerk
div1.p: Published February 8th, 1886.
div1.ab: STATE OF WASHINGTON, County of King, City of Seattle,
ss.
div1.p: I, Jas Riplinger, City Comptroller and ex-officio City Clerk of the City of Seattle do hereby certify that the within and foregoing is a true and correct copy of Ordinance No. 710 as the same appears on file in my office.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF I have set my hand and affixed the seal of the City of Seattle this 4th day of September, A. D. 1902.
div1.ab: Jas Riplinger City Comptroller and ex-officio City Clerk of the City of Seattle.
By E.W. Melor Dep.
Orginal
Tx
of the Nothern this 4th ofSeptember, 1902. Wiestling
Attorney for Petitioner
In the United States District Court FOR THE DISTRICT of Washington Northern Division
In the matter of the application of Lee Fong for a writ of Habeas Corpus
Answer to Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
FILED IN THE U.S. DISTRICT COURT, DIST OF WASHINGTON. SEP 4 1902 R.M. HOPKINS, CLERK
HM Matthew Deputy
Mitchell Gillian Ellis D E Bruler
Attorney for John Sullivan Chief of Police.
